'''Clinton Williams "Clint" Murchison Sr.''' (April 11, 1895 &ndash; June 20, 1969)<ref name="Van Buren">{{cite web|last=Van Buren|first=Ernestine Orrick|title=Murchison, Clinton Williams Sr.|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fmu10|work=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=February 8, 2013}}</ref> was a noted [[Texas]]-based [[petroleum|oil]] magnate and political operative. Among his companies was the [[Southern Union Company]]. He was also the father of [[Dallas Cowboys]] owner [[Clint Murchison Jr.]].<ref name="Chicago Tribune; June 21, 1969">{{cite news |last= |first= |date=June 21, 1969 |title=Murchison Sr. Dies; Fortune near ½ billion |url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1969/06/21/page/78/article/murchison-sr-dies-fortune-near-1-2-billion |newspaper=Chicago Tribune |location=Chicago |agency=UPI |accessdate=December 31, 2014}}</ref>

==Personal==
Murchison, the third child of John Weldon and Clara Lee Murchison, was born April 11, 1895 in [[Tyler, Texas]].<ref name="Cockrell School of Engineering">{{cite web|title=Clint W. Murchison Sr.|url=http://www.engr.utexas.edu/cofe/about/544-clint-w-murchison-sr|work=http://www.engr.utexas.edu|publisher=The University of Texas at Austin|accessdate=February 8, 2013|author=Cockrell School of Engineering|authorlink=Cockrell School of Engineering|location=Austin, Texas|year=2013}}</ref>

During [[World War I]], Murchison served as a [[first lieutenant#U.S. Army.2C U.S. Marine Corps and U.S. Air_Force|first lieutenant]] in the [[United States Army]].<ref name="Van Buren"/> He later joined [[Sid W. Richardson]] as lease traders in the Burkburnett oilfield in 1919.<ref name="Van Buren"/>

Murchison owned several ranches, one in northeastern [[Mexico]], where he hosted the [[Edward VIII|Duke]] and [[Wallis Simpson|Duchess]] of [[Duke of Windsor|Windsor]] in 1950.<ref name="St. Petersburg Times">{{cite news|title=Windsor And Wife Leave For Visit in Tallahassee|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=888&dat=19500129&id=ZltIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=H04DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5450,4994537|accessdate=October 30, 2013|newspaper=St. Petersburg Times|date=January 29, 1950|location=St. Petersburg|page=014}}</ref>

==Family==
In 1920, Murchison married Anne Morris from [[Tyler, Texas]]<!-- source/citation needed for date of birth and date of death (b. 1898, d. 1926) --> and they had three sons: John Dabney Murchison (September 5, 1921 &ndash; June 14, 1979), [[Clint Murchison, Jr.|Clinton Williams Murchison, Jr.]] (September 12, 1923 &ndash; March 30, 1987<!-- source/citation needed for date of death -->), and Burk Murchison (January 26, 1925 &ndash; April 15, 1936).<ref name="Cockrell School of Engineering"/><ref name="Van Buren"/>  His 1st wife, Anne Morris Murchison, died in 1926.<ref name="Van Buren"/> Murchison married again in 1943 to Virginia Long from [[Commerce, Texas]].<ref name="Van Buren"/>

==Death==
Murchison was reported to have been ill several years prior to his death.<ref name="Chicago Tribune; June 21, 1969"/> On July 20, 1969, he died at Henderson County Memorial Hospital in [[Athens, Texas]].<ref name="Van Buren"/> At the time of his death, Murchison's fortune was estimated to be $500,000,000.<ref name="Chicago Tribune; June 21, 1969"/>

==JFK conspiracy allegations==
[[Madeleine Duncan Brown]], an advertising executive who previously claimed to have had an extended love affair and a son with President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]], said that she was present at a party in Murchison's Dallas home on the evening prior to the [[assassination of John F. Kennedy]] that was attended by Johnson as well as other famous, wealthy, and powerful individuals including [[J. Edgar Hoover]], [[Richard Nixon]], and [[H. L. Hunt]].<ref name=Aynesworth>{{cite news|last=Aynesworth|first=Hugh|authorlink=Hugh Aynesworth|title=‘One-man truth squad’ still debunking JFK conspiracy theories|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/local-news/20121117-one-man-truth-squad-still-debunking-jfk-conspiracy-theories.ece|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=The Dallas Morning News|date=November 17, 2012|location=Dallas}}</ref> According to Brown, Johnson had a meeting with several of the men after which he told her: “After tomorrow, those goddamn Kennedys will never embarrass me again. That’s no threat. That’s a promise.”<ref name=Aynesworth/>{{#tag:ref|Brown provided a similar account on ''A Current Affair'' stating: "On the day of the assassination, not but a couple of hours prior to the assassination, he said that John Kennedy would never embarrass him again and that wasn't a threat - that was a promise."<ref name="Boston Herald">{{cite news|title=Celebrity|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/bostonherald/access/68772275.html?dids=68772275:68772275&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Feb+24%2C+1992&author=&pub=Boston+Herald&desc=celebrity&pqatl=google|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=Boston Herald|date=February 24, 1992|location=Boston|page=015}}</ref>|group="nb"|name=""}} Brown's story received national attention and became part of at least a dozen [[John F. Kennedy assassination conspiracy theories]].<ref name=Aynesworth/>
